Award.AwardTitle: Geochemical tracers to establish the significance and timing of gas hydrate induced slide failure in the Hikurangi margin, as a component of the SLAMZ project
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the relationship between landslides and gas hydrate formation on the northeastern Hikurangi margin of New Zealand. Submarine landslides pose a significant socio-economic hazard, not only because they may destabilize offshore installations (e.g. underwater cables), but more significantly because the tsunamis generated by such slope failures have caused significant human fatalities and destruction of coastal infrastructure. The Hikurangi margin off New Zealand is ideally suited to study the various processes known to act as drivers/preconditioners for slope failure. The project will assess the importance of many factors on slope stability including gas hydrates and sediment composition and diagenesis (e.g., what makes a particular sedimentary layer weak); tectonic stress and geometry (e.g., slope steepening); and margin hydrogeology (e.g., transient pore pressure changes associated with climate and faulting). The geochemical component of this project complements a large, international, multi-year German-led project termed Slide Activity on the Hikurangi Margin, New Zealand (SLAMZ). Results from this study will serve to test various current ideas on the role of gas hydrate on slope stability, and will also address issues such as the water and carbon budgets along the margin and the presence and extent of fluid flow within the sediments. The results will thus have a broader relevance in the context of our understanding of the hydrogeology, element cycling, and earthquake generation in subduction zones worldwide. The project includes the training of an undergraduate student as well as mentoring of a postdoctoral investigator.

Submarine slope failure is a major sedimentary process along ocean margins worldwide, with consequences that include margin architecture, hydrogeology and tsunamogenesis. Numerous studies have proposed that gas hydrates play a major role in controlling slope failure initiation and mass-movement processes, including a new hypothesis that postulates that gas hydrate itself may lead to seafloor weakening through plastic, very slow (creeping) deformation similar to rock glaciers in the terrestrial environment. In contrast to the extensive geophysical and near-seafloor data sets available for the Hikurangi margin, there is a lack of deep core geochemical data to address the interdependence of fluid, temperature, and gas hydrate dynamics in slope stability. This project aims at generating the first data set on geochemical parameters that complements ongoing geophysical, petrophysical and modeling efforts to unravel the role of gas hydrate in slope stability of the Hikurangi Margin in a partnership with scientists from Germany and New Zealand. The SLAMZ program (led by the University of Bremen) will use a seafloor to sample sediment at eight locations with contrasting tectonic settings and geometries, depth of gas hydrate stability, slump characteristics and fluid flow. The geochemical component of this large international project will generate and analyze pore fluid data that are key to: 1) Establish distribution and concentration of gas hydrate; 2) Evaluate postulated changes in gas hydrate stability associated with seamount subduction; 3) Constrain transients associated with gas hydrate and sediment slumping processes; and 4) Detect and characterize the nature and sources of fluid flow. Our results will contribute to our understanding of the geochemical, and geomechanical transformations in gas-hydrate bearing subduction zones, with implications to the societally-relevant processes that contribute to slope instability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plain Language Summary

This project addresses slope failure and gas hydrate processes on the north-eastern Hikurangi margin of New Zealand that are relevant to continental margins worldwide. Submarine landslides pose a significant socio-economic hazard, not only because they may destabilize offshore installations (e.g. underwater cables), but more significantly because the tsunamis generated by such slope failures have caused significant human fatalities and destruction of coastal infrastructure. The geochemical component of this project funded by NSF complements a large, international, multi-year project that includes geophysical imaging, scientific drilling, sampling, laboratory work and modeling studies.

Within the Hikurangi margin, the Tuaheni Landslide Complex (TLC) displays morphological features that are typical of active, slow-moving terrestrial earthflows and rock glaciers. Intriguingly, the upper limit of creeping coincides with the depth in the seafloor where gas hydrate becomes unstable given the combination of temperature and pressure conditions that determine their stability. By integrating data collected using both the seafloor drill MeBo and the Joides Resolution, we showed that gas hydate is not present within the slide mass, and thus not directly contribute to the slow, creeping behavior of the TLC. Pore-water data collected from the slide mass was modeled to reconstruct its temporal history and its effect on subsurface methane cycling. Our results show that the TLC was formed by two separate depositional events and that the most recent one occurred 12.5±2.5 ka as a coherent ~40 m sediment block. In addition, modeled response of the methane cycling rates to the slide mass emplacement shows that the rapid burial of pore-water sulfate consumed a significant amount of methane over the 12.5 kyr that followed the most recent depositional event. This rapid deposition of sediment played a fundamental role in the gas hydrate stability below the slide mass. We showed that it was this rapid sedimentation, rather than changes in sealevel at the last glacial/interglacial transition what controlled gas hydrate dynamics in this margin, and possibly other margins as well. Our numerical simulations do not provide support for previous hypotheses that large scale gas hydrate dissociation across the most recent glacial/interglacial caused widespread gas release and large slope failure events. These results are consistent with observations that there is no methane signal in atmospheric records associated with gas hydrate dissociation at the last glacial/interglacial transition.

Geochemical analyses using samples collected with the MeBo seafloor drill were also valuable in establishing the importance of ash alteration on methane budgets in this margin, specifically, we present several lines of evidence that point to oxidation of methane by iron released from volcanogenic ash deposition. We estimated the rate of iron-mediated oxidation of methane to be on the order of 0.4 μmol cm-2 yr-1, which accounts for ~12% of total CH4 removal in the sediments east of New Zealand’s North Island. Although this rate is significantly lower than methane consumption by sulfate, our results show that iron in ash can potentially serve as an electron acceptor for methane oxidation in sulfate-depleted settings. This is relevant to our understanding of carbon-iron cycling in the methanic zone, and the role of ash in supporting the deep biosphere.

In summary, results from this study addressed hypotheses on the role of gas hydrate on slope stability, role of mass transport on gas hydrate dynamics as well as first order issues such as the carbon budgets and carbon cycling along the margin, which can be applicable to other margins where both ash and gas hydrate deposits are present.
